There is not a clear theoretical model for the "Hollow Earth".
The "Agartha map" makes us think of Earth as a thick egg shell. That is misleading.
The model should be an apple. Here are the reasonings for that hypotesis.

When having a rotating heterogeneous fluid sphere in space, the more dense parts are displaced to the outside due to the angular acceleration, creating a less dense materials axis of rotation.
Here a 1 minute video about that phenomenon:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BxyfiBGCwhQ

When that sphere reaches a planetary size, the force of gravity pressures the materials to the center of the sphere, creating the Earth's core according to the "standard scientific planetary model".
Could be that core be a plasma? That is open to investigation.

The combination of angular acceleration and gravity makes us believe in a "lower density" in the polar regions.
And that is why I said the "Hollow Earth" model should be an apple, with "theoretical entrances" at the poles.

We also have to consider what would be the effect of geologic tectonic movements of the Earth's crust, wich tends to "uniform" the crust in the shape of a perfect sphere.

Conclusion:
Is it possible a Hollow Earth in reality?
Yes, but the theoretical model is not what is usually presented in alternative research media.
The polar regions are the main candidates for "inner worlds", but their size would be limited due to gravity and tectonic movements.

Excellent video. Sorry, incorrect about coming to rest at the other side (great opportunity for a follow up video). You've assumed that the DURATION of acceleration at high and low gravitational effect are mirror images either side of the centre/core, they aren't. The first half of the distance starts with low velocity and ends at vmax. This means that the duration spent at high gravitation is far longer than the duration spent nearer micro gravitation. Loads of acceleration. Then, however the second half of the distance starts with vmax at low gravitation, far less TIME spent there than before, then the vessel is still at quite high velocity when entering the high gravitational effect nearer the surface, and spends less TIME in that effect. If anyone has trouble understanding this please familiarise yourself with the gravitational slingshot. Decades ago engineers used it to make the Voyager probes the fastest machines ever made. So actually you'd fly out of the other side and probably (not sure) break away from the atmosphere, then slowly get attracted back, but at extremely high altitude. It would actually repeat, think of it as a very UNSTABLE orbit (obviously ignoring air, the moon or other bodies).

NO, actually if you put a person inside a hollow sphere, then gravity would cause the sphere shell to be attracted to the person. So this video is lying or stupid or wrong about "the shell theorem" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shell_theorem. The wikipedia is wrong about shell theorem too and if you are mathematical minded instead of just trusting whatever scientist on wikipida say you can tell how it's wrong. The mass of whatever object is inside the sphere is assumed to be zero which is of course impossible. So yes, if you had an object with zero mass inside a sphere then the sphere would not be attracted to the zero mass object inside of it. BUT if the object inside the sphere does have mass, then it attracts towards itself the closest side of the spherical shell.

Earth does not have any magnetic molten core. Curie temperature of iron: 1,060 F. Melting point of iron 2,800 F. Earth's crust is 5.6% iron and that is where the magnet is.
An Earth magnet blocking gamma rays from the Sun? LOL. That's like wearing a refrigerator magnet for protection during a tour of Chernobyl. Magnets do not stop or bend gamma or x-rays. That whole concept is fictional science.

The aurorae are lightning filaments caused by the friction of (static electricity created by) gases moving vertically in opposite directions. Those gases are moved primarily by polar jets which shoot out of the north and south poles. How are gases shooting out of the poles if Earth is solid inside?

The gravity thing is an interesting dilemma which I have not conquered. Your model is mathematically justified but false. It assumes an Earth of zero depth - zero distance between in the inner and outer surfaces. That model may be fairly accurate for an object towards the center, but cannot be true for an object on or near the inner surface where the crust has thickness.

Concerning atmosphere, the solar wind contains hydrogen, helium, oxygen, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, ammonia, and other gases - an endless supply of atmosphere to every planet. Every planet holds all the atmosphere it can. If Earth were hollow, with a crustal depth of 730 kilometers, the Earth interior atmosphere or innosphere weighs 2.59E+19 kilograms and atmospheric pressure is 5x the pressure on the outer surface. You took your 'zero gravity' concept the wrong direction there. You must calculate the total gravity - not the net gravity - the understand inner atmosphere physics.

Gravity on the surface, I agree, would be exactly what we experience. However, a hollow Earth determines a different gravitational constant, meaning that all the masses of the whole universe must be recalculated and - when this is done properly - dark matter and dark energy cease to mathematically exist.

How can gravity be zero everywhere inside the hollow earth? That's impossible. Depending on your position inside the hollow earth, the strength of gravity will be different. So if you are on the inner surface, you will be pulled towards the inner surface as the pull of gravity is stronger towards the surface below you compared to the surface above you which is 7100 km away. Only at the exact center of earth you will experience zero gravity because you are being pulled evenly from all sides at the exact center of earth. Deviate from the center of earth and you slowly begin to fall towards the inner surface as gravitational pull becomes more and more uneven in strength. That pull of gravity away from the center of earth towards the shell naturally creates a huge cavity inside all planets making them naturally formed hollow. Its that simple. Dude, take a metallurgy class. There is no "Molten magnetic core". Iron demagnetizes when it goes through its first "phase change" (change in crystalline structure arrangement) at about 900 degrees fahrenheit. You can demonstrate this for yourself (I have) by magnetizing an iron bar, and then heating it up with a torch until it turns a cherry red color. This does not prove that the earth is hollow, but it does prove that the core or the earth is:
A. Significantly cooler than 900 degrees fahrenheit. (iron becomes molten at approx. 2780 degrees fahrenheit)
B. That the earth's core is not responsible for the planet's magnetic field. (metallic elements in the earth's crust are responsible for the earth's magnetic field, or some other unconsidered reason)?

Guillaume Roy - allow replies to comments if you want answers to your questions.  You would expect that the gravitational force would get stronger and stronger as you tunnel into the Earth IF the density of the Earth were uniform.  This is not the case.  The density of the core is much higher than the density of the crust and mantle, so for about a 1/3 of the trip, you are getting closer to much more dense material, therefore - for a while, the force would get stronger until you start to pass into the more dense material - then it would start decreasing.

Sorry guys but this video bares a few flaws. Traveling though a hole drilled other than at the poles, yes you would have to contend with the Coriolis effect of but angle of attack when you hit the wall as you travel would be so shallow as to cause the traveling body to essentially skid off the side of the wall surface during decent with about much the same way as sliding on a bowling alley floor. The cannon ball down the mile deep bore hole would have experienced the same effect as to continue to the bottom unless acted upon by an alternate force, it would have hit bottom. Oh, and the material comprising the wall will no doubt be rock and that becoming more dense with depth. 

It would have of course also reached a terminal velocity, perhaps skidded off the wall a couple times but still and all hit the end of the line. Ya gotta keep in mind that as the ball was dropped it too was traveling at the same velocity as the mouth of the hole. Granted there would be a differential velocity gradient in relation of the falling mass to the tunnel wall over time but NOTHING nearly so forceful as to 'stick' it in the wall. A miner loss of acceleration due to terminal velocity plus a spot of  frictional loss during time of contact with the wall but overall, down ya go.

If you're in a closed box car on a train traveling at 80 mph and drop a ball, it bounces up and falls on the same spot at the floor because the ball and the air in the car are  traveling at 80 mph as well. To simulate the Coriolis effect, let's open the doors at either end of the car just slightly allowing a mild breeze from one end of the car to the other to cause the ball a slight deviation from it's 80 mph horizontal velocity (Coriolis) during drop. Now the ball, once dropped won't hit the same spot but just off a bit in the direction with the air flow. If this were done, say in front of a smooth plate full of small holes to allow air to pass, the ball would then strike and a skid on that plate a short way but only slightly if you get the drift.

Pole to pole and I'm going to re install air (actually makes a little difference. Ya jump in and begin to accelerate at 32 ft. per second per second until such time as you reach terminal velocity around 180 mph (if memory serves correct) this depending of attitude during fall. Side ways, head, feet first what you are wearing etc. etc. But unlike falling half way through toward the other surface, you are falling into a body of much denser mass which mean that all the mass you have passed through still has an attraction and will, over time, begin to slow your decent. You would pass the middle and begin to approach the opposite surface never reaching it as you slow due to loss of energy to gravity and then reverse your decent back toward center.

After several oscillation of this sort, you then would experience a slowing toward equilateral gravity and a feeling of weightlessness IF our hypotheses about the earths structures are true. I do have questions as to this considering the heavier and lighter masses reaction due to differences caused by centrifugal and centripetal forces during the molten stages of the earths formation. Centrifugal force slings heavier masses out while centripetal force causes lighter masses to migrate toward center of rotation. It this were so, and the earth cooled during that epoch, I see it as not beyond reason the the earth may have at least hollow portions to it's interior. That and how as the earths magnetic field is largely unexplainable, hey. Who knows for sure? If I'm wrong, please let me know.

@MinutePhysics Please see what you can do with the following thought, as I don't think I'm quite up to the mathematics involved.   At 2:56 where it's talking about if the Earth were hollow but weighed the same, of course Shell Theorem explains why the gravity should cancel out if the Earth were hollow with a shell thickness of zero. However, it seems to me that an actual physical object would of course have at least SOME thickness no matter what you constructed it out of, which I would think should act as a local enough source of gravity to keep the internal gravity near the surface (and to a lesser extent farther from it) from quite being zero.  

Now, imagine an artificially constructed hollow planet, with periodic holes through the surface distributed like the vertices of a geodesic dome. Imagine that this planet is not Earth sized, but much larger. Perhaps the size of Jupiter or the sun, or a blue giant star... with a surface thickness calculated to give a local gravitational pull from the construction material that would about equal near the surface that of the planet Earth near the surface... of course, with the added weight of an atmosphere figured into the calculations, along with bodies of water and so on. Ignoring, for now, the problems of keeping it at a reasonable temperature, and instead assuming that a way of maintaining comfortable temperatures by human standards was built in, would it be POSSIBLE to make such a planet just the right dimensions and density to have a reasonable air pressure all over both its inner and outer surfaces... or at least one of the two?

If not possible to have both, I am more interested in the possibility of having reasonable air pressure on the inner surface (remember... not a sealed structure), providing a place where humans could live with the surface actually acting as protection from debris hitting the planet.  The air pressure on the outer surface would of course be higher, but I wonder if it could be perhaps low enough that some life could adapt to live on the outer surface.

2:03 This could only happen in a situation where no friction or air resistance exists. If air resistance had occurred, you would've been slowed down, and could not reach the other side. Instead, you would be slingshotted back around, getting less far the longer it went on until you got stuck in the exact center of the earth, where it would be physically impossible to escape. Basically, the center of the earth would be the ultimate prison.

On the other hand, if there was no air resistance, but friction was applied, it would also be impossible, due to even the slightest bit of energy lost making your trip impossible. For example, your heart pumping and your blood speeding around your body would make you lose energy, as would breathing, blinking, and even making contact with your clothing.

I would also like to point out that it would be impossible for non-air resistance or friction to exist. Friction is pretty much a LAW of nature, and any object that's actually large enough to propel you through itself at even an eighth of the speed mentioned in this video will have an atmosphere of SOMETHING thanks to it's gravitational pull.

So, with a hollow earth, on the surface one would still weigh the same as he does now.  However, were he to dig a hole and climb immediately below the surface (or shell), due to the equalization of gravity within a hollow sphere, he would be weightless.  I find this very strange.

Imagine a shell of only 1mm (yes, extremely dense).  Climbing from below the surface to the surface would have a very odd sensation as each part of your body would almost instantaneously (over the 1mm distance) go from no weight to the full weight that you're used to as it rose from within the sphere.

Now imagine a shell of 1m.  Your weight would gradually change from zero at 1m depth to full weight at the surface.  Given uniform density of the shell, the change would not be linear, but proportional to the cube of the distance from 1m depth.

I'd appreciate it if someone would please confirm this or tell me where I'm wrong.

Geologist here:

EARTH IS NOT LIQUID ON THE INSIDE!

Beyond a certain point (kilometers down) it ceases to deform brittley and starts to deform ductilly. Instead of breaking, things bend. As you got deeper, the pressure would increase like whoa (though if you have a hollow space around you that hasn't been crushed by lithostatic pressure, I suppose that wouldn't be so much a problem).

We speculate that the outer core is a liquid because of the geodynamo system and because of the effects on seismic waves, but we really know next to nothing about the core (I personally think that there are far more rare earth elements down there than meteors would suggest, but that's a different story).

The Kola Superdeep Hole did not reach that far down, it didn't even reach the Asthenosphere. Either Way: NOT LIQUID!

It's actually interesting to think about, and it makes total sense.  It does not matter which gravitational field you are falling in, or how many different fields are acting on you at the same time - - or what your acceleration is (classically) relative to some body (9.8m/s² on Earth - 1.6 m/s² on the moon, etc.).  Being in free fall in ANY gravitational field is IDENTICAL to being in deep space and having no forces acting on you whatsoever.  It makes sense that gravity is not an actual force.

Einstein's equivalence principal (which is what I just described) is one of the reasons he concluded that falling in a gravitational field was actually inertial motion.  Inertial motion is just any motion that is uniform under the influence of zero forces.  He also concluded that standing on the surface of the Earth was actually the accelerated motion.  Because of this, he came to the assumption that gravity was not a force, but a curvature of space which we follow inertially when falling.

Are you talking about 'The Fall' in the remake of 'Total Recall'?  I can't tell what this comment is in response to, but it could be in response to mine.  If so, when I say you would float freely, I meant you would float freely relative to the container that was falling with you; not relative to the Earth, and this relative 'floating' would occur as long as you were in free fall - - not just when you reach the center of the Earth (and flip for some reason)- like they portrayed in the movie.

Not according to Einstein, and the concept makes sense, but I don't think that is what jon p is talking about.

Accelerating due to gravity is unlike any other acceleration we encounter.  It is identical to floating in free space and having no forces acting on you whatsoever (weightlessness).  Standing on the surface of the Earth (what classical mechanics would consider inertial motion (ignoring rotation)) is the exact same thing as being accelerated at 9.8 m/s² on a platform in deep space.

The Earth has a radius of about 6371 kilometers (it varies between the equator and poles). That gives us 6,371,000 meters as the long leg (a) of a right triangle with a hypotenuse (c) of 6,371,001 meters.

Pythagoras says that c^2 -a^2 =b^2, so the board for the short leg of the triangle has to be 3,569.594 meters long. If that seems long, consider that the angle between the long leg and the hypotenuse would still be only .00056º.

If you couldn't go 'against gravity', then you couldn't throw a ball in the air.  When you throw a ball in the air, you gave it some initial velocity, and the height it reaches depends on that velocity.  When something falls 'through Earth', when it reaches the center, it has velocity from all the acceleration from falling - and essentially - you can think of it as being thrown from the center of the Earth with an initial velocity equal to the velcotiy from all that acceleration.

There is nothing special causing gravity to pull toward the center.  It is because we are all on the outside of the Earth, and every grain, rock, pebble from East to West is pulling on you - - and if you were to sum all those vectors together, the result (net force) would act toward the center of the Earth since it is a sphere.  If you are AT the center - then all the mass is surrounding you equally, and the sum of all vectors would be zero (no net force).

In other words, gravitation is symmetrical.  What goes up must come down, and if all other factors are ignored - which AGAIN this video makes very clear they ARE ignored - then the properties of the upward swing are exactly opposite to the properties of the downward swing.

All this being said, I will repeat that at no point do the maker(s) of these videos claim that this is everything or that you should watch their videos before taking a physics exam.  However, they are not wrong either.

Ignore drag - JUST like the video-pay attention to the variables.

1)  An object with an initial velocity of 'v(o)' dropped straight down from height, 'h' falls for 't' seconds, will have a final velocity, 'v(f)'.  It will have travelled distance, 'd'.

2)  An object propelled straight up with initial velocity, 'v(f)' will reach a maximum height of 'h', travel a distance, 'd' to reach that height, and it will take 't' seconds to reach that height and have a velocity of 'v(o)' at that height.

The 8km/s mentioned in this video is not really a 'maximum velocity'.  It just happens to be the velocity an object reaches when it reaches the center of Earth after it has been accelerating due to gravity from the surface.  If no energy is lost - which this video clearly assumes - then the falling body will reach a height on the other side of Earth that is equal to the original height jumped from.  This is fundamental gravitation.  I will continue this point in the last post.

You are talking about terminal velocity, and a prerequisite for that is drag.  They categorically say that it is assumed there is no air resistance, so there would be no terminal velocity.

Tides on Earth are the result of the force of gravity from the moon being stronger on the side that faces the moon - and weaker on the opposite side.  There are two high tides - one on the near side of the moon, and one on the opposite side.  The reason there are two is because the water on the near side is getting pulled more, and the water on the opposite side is getting 'left behind' because of the weaker pull of gravity.

Anyway - since you are so small, there are no tidal forces on you.

One factor in determining the force of gravity is your distance to the center of mass (of the Eath in this example).  From your feet to the center is ~6,375,000.  From your head to the center is maybe 1.5 meters more, so there is no noticeable difference in force.  Now, the force of the moon on the Earth is a different story.  The Earth is so massive that the difference in gravitational force from the moon varies significantly, and this is what causes tides - hence the name 'tidal forces'.

The force on every cell in your body is exactly the same in all directions and is consistent throughout your body.  Because of this, it is exactly the same as having no forces acting on you.  They all cancel each other.  The only way for gravity to 'rip you apart' would be if there was a significant difference in the force on one part of your body and another, and you are WAY too small for the force to vary over the course of your body.  These are known as tidal forces.  Explained further.....

correction - prop and jet planes use fuel in an entirely different way than ROCKET engines....sorry for the mistake.

1)  A gun WILL fire in space - as long as you are using modern ammunition

2)  Prop planes, jet planes, and rockets ALL utilize Newton's third law of motion.  Prop and Jet planes push air - the equal and opposite reaction is thrust.  While prop and jet planes USE fuel, they use it in an entirely different way than jet engines.  Prop and jet engines use fuel to turn props or turbines that in turn push the air.  A jet engine pushes the fuel itself - not air.  It expells the fuel, and causes thrust

The reason a human (or anything else) reaches a terminal velocity is because eventually it will be going so fast that the force of drag is equal to the force of gravity (drag = weight).  In the video, they specifically say that in their 'mind experiment' of falling through the Earth, there is no air - it is a vacuum.  In a vacuum, there is no drag, so there is no terminal velocity since drag equals ZERO no matter how fast you are falling.

Because it is the rate in which velocity changes.  If you are going 1 m/s, and 1 second later, you are going 2 m/s, and then another second goes by and you are then going 3 m/s, then your velocity is increasing by 1 m/s.....every second.  So your acceleration is 1 meter per second....per second.  The reason you square the seconds is because mathematically, it is m/s/s (meters divided by seconds divided by seconds).  So m/s/s mathematically equals m/s². (16/2/2 = 16/2²)

In other words, the reason the coriolis effect exists is because a projectile is moving along a surface that is rotating and the radius of that rotation is changing significantly enough that the lateral motion of the surface changes noticeably.  When you move east to west or vice versa, the radius of rotation does not change, so the coriolis effect does not happen.

No.  If the only motion is along the rotational east-west axis, then the coriolis effect does not apply.  What DOES happen is a bullet with an eastward trajectory will have a slightly higher centripetal acceleration than a bullet fired westward due to the same rotation of the Earth that causes the coriolis effect, but this is not the coriolis effect at work.  It's just changes in centripetal acceleration.

albeit the waves will be weaker depending on distance so the Epicenter has the strongest readings and, radiating outwardly, more distant seismographs get weaker and weaker readings.

Interestingly there are "Silent Zones" where the radiating P-waves happen not to reach certain areas Vertically South-west and South-east through the earth. The S-waves also dont reach them because S-waves cant travel through Liquids, so they are cancelled out by the liquid core and dont reach those areas.

Well an earthquake is really a release of enormous energy with two large masses either slipping or pushing each other. This release of energy is transmitted via raves such as the Shear and P-waves.

Shear is a transverse wave, moving in a Sine-like wave motion. P-waves are Longitudinal, moving like water waves or compression waves. Compression waves can travel through solids, like the video about a lightyear long ruler, compression waves move through solids and liquids and can reach everywhere.

Oh and also the moon can't be hollow either as it came from Earth. It was formed when a large meteor (or maybe even another planet) collided with Earth while its mantle and core were still forming. The collision launched rock from earth into space and most of it started to orbit the planet. Over time the debris had collected and began forming the moon. We know this because the moon has almost identical ratios of Niobium to Tantalum to Earth. Most other space rock has a far higher ratio.

The reason the seismographs all pick up earthquakes is because once you pass the crust you get to the mantle which is liquid rock, and the rest is all liquid until you get to the core with is thought to be nickle or iron but we're not sure. Anyway, its like dropping a rock into water, it ripples. Same with earthquakes it ripples through the liquid rock inside the planet and you can detect it everywhere else.

The rules concerning was/were are a bit odd. Summarized 'If I/it were' would be used when stating something that is counterfactual, while 'If I/it was' would be used if something is actually true. For example the statement 'If the Earth were hollow' obviously isn't true, therefore 'were' is used. In the sentence 'I was born in 1992', the statement would be correct, therefore 'was' is used.

The reason there is no net gravitational force inside a hollow sphere has nothing to do with electromagnetism.  It still follows the laws of gravitation.  Obviously, when you are at the exact center, there is an equal amount of mass all at equal distances from you.  As soon as you move away from the center, you are moving closer to less mass and farther from more mass, and since mass and distance are what determine gravity, the result is always a force that nets to zero.

The force of gravity on you is NOT the same when you are falling through the Earth.  The force of gravity is caused by mass.  The Earth is more dense toward the center, so for a little while (like he said) the force of gravity DOES increase.  But once you reach a certain point, the mass of the Earth that you have already passed is pulling you in the opposite direction as the mass below you, so it begins to cancel.

Once in the interior of the hollow Earth, whatever velocity you had when you entered, you would maintain.  You would not be pulled toward the center.  You would be pulled equally in all directions no matter where you are in the hollow Earth.  The force of gravity increases the closer you are to mass, and the more mass there is.  So anywhere inside, if you are closer to some mass, you are ALWAYS farther from MORE mass.  It always cancels.  Search "Newton's shell theorem" for more info.

Imagine you are on a merry-go-round.  Suppose that merry-go-round makes 1 revolution per second.  Someone who is half way from the edge to the center of the merry-go-round is making the exact same number of revolutions as someone who is halfway from the edge to the center; 1 per second.  The difference is, the person on the edge is traveling a longer distance in that 1 second than the person halfway to the center.

There are the same number of revolutions toward the center as there are at the surface.  The difference is that the 'sphere' that rotates gets smaller as you approach the center.  This means that the rotational speed of the 'sphere' as you approach the center gets slower and slower.  So, you WOULD run into the side, but not because there are more revolutions.  That is why the hypothesized tunnel through Earth in this video is from pole to pole.  The rotational speed would be zero here.

Density doesn't have to be uniform for Newton's Shell Theorem. 

Acceleration increases in this case because, as you've said, the closer you are to the core, the higher the force of gravity. Then as the density of the Earth is concentrated towards the center, as you get closer, Newton's Shell Theorem excludes less mass from the equation, F = Gmm/r^2, and the "r^2" factor decreases faster than the "m" factor from mass being excluded from Shell Theorem.

In Newton's shell theorem, it is assumed that density is uniform.  In this case, the acceleration due to gravity would indeed decrease as you moved toward the center.  However, the Earth's density is not uniform, but is concentrated in the core.  The acceleration due to gravity can be calculated using this formula, which I derived using gravitation, Newton's 2nd law, Volume, and density.

a=4/3Gπrp

a = acceleration
G = 6.67*10^-11
r = radius
p = density in kg/m³

a=G*4/3*pi*r*p

No.  All gravitational forces would cancel each other out within a hollow sphere no matter where you are in that sphere.  This is Newton's shell theorem.  It has been proven mathematically.  Gravity depends on mass and your distance to it.  When you are in the exact center, there is an equal amount of mass all around you at equal distances.  The farther you move off center, the closer you get to less mass, and farther from more mass.  It always cancels.  Even if you are right next to the wall.

Yes, mass creates gravity.  ANY two objects with mass are attracted to each other.  You are attracted to a speck of dust on the other side of Earth.  You are attracted to every particle of mass that makes up the Earth (and the Earth to you equally and opposite).  When you are standing on the surface, all these forces net directly toward the center.  When at the center, all the mass is surrouding you equally, so you are pulled in every direction (toward the surface) equally, netting to zero.

So your saying that gravity is dependent on the mass of your surroundings, which creates the gravity?
But from the perspective of being on the surface, it would seem that gravity directed towards the person, who is at the center.

No.  The claim that gravity acts toward the center of Earth is just a convenient simplification when you are OUTSIDE the Earth.  Since it is a sphere, then you can assume that its entire mass is concentrated at the center.  Standing on the surface, each particle of mass is pulling on you in many directions.  All the vectors net toward the center.  In the center of the Earth, the mass is all around you pulling you toward the surface, but the vectors net to ZERO.  No direction; no magnitude.

No. This part of the video is from Newton's shell theorem.  The relevant part of the theorem states that any object inside a hollowed out sphere will experience a net gravitational force of zero.  The reason for this is because the gravitational force depends on two things.  The mass, and your distance to that mass.  When you are right next to a wall, there isn't that much mass pulling you to that wall.  Most of the mass is pulling you in the opposite direction.  These forces always cancel.
Wouldn't the gravity be asymmetrical if you were inside the shell but not at the center? Pulling you towards the closer side of the shell?

The reason is because the amount of mass is not the only thing that determines the force of gravity.  Your distance to the center of that mass is also a factor.  So as you fall closer to the most dense part of the Earth, the gravitational force will get stronger because while there is technically less mass below you, you are closer to the center of mass that is a lot denser on average.  This only happens up to a certain point, and as you get beyond this point, the force gets weaker and weaker.

Astronauts are free falling in orbit in the ISS, and they were free falling all the way to the moon because the only force acting on those astronauts is gravity.  That's what falling is.

When you are standing on the surface, your potential energy is at its greatest, and kenetic energy is 0.  Since no energy is lost, while you are falling, potential energy is being converted into kenetic energy.  At the center, potential energy will be 0 and kenetic energy will be equal to the starting potential energy.  The process works in reverse from the center to the other side, and you will end up right where you started.  Conservation of energy.  (drag ignored; this would be heat energy)

Now, on Earth, it is unlikely that the distance from the surface to the center from where you jumped in is exactly the same as the distance from the center to the surface on the other side of Earth (because of varying terrain), but since this video is obviously taking liberties with likelihood, it is also assumed that for the purposes of this mind experiment, the Earth is a perfect sphere and no drag exists.  So, you would 'fall' just far enough to reach the lip of the other side of Earth.

You are always accelerating toward the center of the Earth.  If you are at rest in the center, you will not move; you will be weightless, but that is not the case in this scenario.  You started accelerating toward the center from the surface, so by the time you reach the center, you have enormous speed and you will 'fly' past the center, then begin to slow down (accelerate toward the center).  You will run out of energy at the same distance from the center as you started on the other side.

The main reason this theorem is relevant doesn't have anything to do with a 'hollow Earth' or other similar mind experiments (although it is just as valid within these scenarios), but rather calculating the gravitational force being exerted when you are drilling a hole into the Earth (or something similar).  When calculating the gravitational force, you only need to consider mass that is INSIDE your current radius to the center because anything outside that radius cancels and can be ignored.

According to the theorem, yes.  The reason this is the case is because while the gravitational force weakens as you move farther away from it, it is also dependent on the amount of mass.  In other words, when you are right next to a 'wall' in that sphere, there isn't all that much mass pulling you DIRECTLY to that wall.  There is mass pulling you left, right, and MOST of the mass (while farther away) is pulling you toward the other side.  The distance to, and amount of mass always cancel.

What you described is Newton's first law of motion; not conservation of energy.  Conservation of energy is a very different idea.  When you reach the center, your gravityational potential energy is zero; not at its peak.  It's kinetic energy is at it's peak at the center.  Think of kinetic energy as potential energy that is being put to use.  Before you jumped, and when you reach the other side are the points where potential energy are at their peak.

Imagine that you had a flashlight inside.  If you are next to a wall, and shine the flashlight on the near wall, it will light up only a small area, whereas if you shine it at the far side, a very large portion of the sphere will be lit. No matter where you shine your light, the gravitational pull from the mass that is lit is equal to any other area you can light up. When you are next to a wall, there isn't really all that much mass exerting a force on you. Most of the mass is on the other side.

Gravity is also dependent on the mass of the object.  In other words, the more mass there is, the stronger the gravitational force.  When you move from the center, you are closer to the mass that you moved toward, but there is also more mass in the opposite direction.  Since distance AND mass affect gravity, the forces will always cancel.  Getting closer to the 'wall' of the hollow sphere means there is that much more mass pulling you away from that wall.  It is farther away, so it cancels.

Nope, sorry thekkl.  This has already been proven by Sir Isaac Newton in his shell theorem.  The gravitational forces inside a hollow sphere exert a net force of zero on you anywhere within that sphere.  You could only stand on the crust from the OUTSIDE of the sphere, and there (anywhere outside), gravitational forces are identical to what they are now.  You can use this theorem to calculate the force on you in a deep hole.  Any mass outside your radius to the center cancels and can be ignored.

No, it applies to anywhere within the sphere.  This is Newton's shell theorem which has been proven.  All the forces net to zero ANYWHERE within the sphere.  Another way to use the theorem is to determine the gravitational force on you somewhere within the Earth as it is now (solid sphere).  You only have to calculate for the mass that is below your radius because all the mass that is outside your radius cancels to zero and can be ignored.  Again, Newton's shell theorem. And as is the case in the scenario in this video, Newton's shell theorem shows that the same is true for a hollow sphere.  All the gravity inside nets to zero.

You are misunderstanding the shell theorem.  As you move inside a sphere, ALL mass above your current radius will exert ZERO gravitational force on you.  The only mass that will exert a gravitational force on you is the mass that is within your current radius.  And in a hollow sphere, there IS no mass within your radius, so ANYWHERE inside, the gravity is ZERO.  It applies ANYWHERE within a hollow sphere, and Newton has a proof that this is mathematically undeniable.  Why can't you accept this?

He is talking about a virtual shell. Like jump in a hole at the North Pole and pop out at the South Pole. The closer you get to the center the less gravity force because mass on all sides balances. Yes it works for our shell’s center, but any other place inside the theory no longer applies. As you fall in to the egg shell, the only relevant mass is the shell wall. Moving away from the wall is against highest force and being in the center is a higher energy state, not a lower one like real earth.

It doesn't matter if it is a "spherical homogeneous solid" or a hollow sphere.  The theorem works for both.  You must not have studied it thoroughly because Newton DOES specify what would happen inside a hollow ball.  It is how the theorem works, so using a hollow ball is a good way to explain it.  The reason for the 'solid' application is because that is a real world application.  It says clearly that if you are within a solid ball, then any mass above your radius can be ignored as if hollow.

Its CALLED the SHELL theorem for a reason.  For example, if you wanted to determine what the gravitational pull would be on you if you were to dig a tunnel down inside the Earth, the shell theorem states that you only need to consider what is within the radius of where you are, and you can ignore the gravitational forces for anything above the radius of where you are because all those forces will cancel out. But rather because of a lack of light and heat. The only remedy to this solution would be to have a molten magnetic core suspended in the middle by gravity and heated by tidal friction. Finally, gravity would not simply fail inside a hollow planet; the closest part of the earth would have more gravity, due to being closer than the other side of the planet. The earth wouldn't collapse on itself because of a keystone configuration; each surface point supports every other surface point it touches.

The idea of a hollow earth isn't that far-fetched, although the theory would definitely need to be modified. I would assume that to have a hollow earth with a magnetic field, it would need a concentrated magnetic column running from pole to pole that generates the field, like that white cord in the middle of an orange. Aside from that, the inside would be almost uninhabitable, not due to lack of air (gravity would allow air to concentrate toward the inner surface)(cont.)

>"gravity flows out of the Earth, not inward"

Gravity flows out from every particle with mass. The Earth is made of many particles with mass, and they're mostly in one direction relative to you, which we call "down". If we were surrounded by a hollow mass equivalent to the Earth, "down" would be in every direction -- but sometimes one down is more down-er than the others.

Well, you would be smeared into a bloodstain (and good luck reaching that one) pretty quickly. Even if you could make it to the center you'd never make it out the other side because of all the speed you'd have lost from being ripped apart on the side of the tunnel. 

You'd make it past the center getting dragged the whole way, then get dragged back past the center (this time less far across it) the other way, and repeat until you'd lost all momentum. A particularly brutal pendulum.

I don't get this coriolis effect. If you jump into the earth and crash into the side wall of your tunnel, what's preventing you from going further down? The force of gravity still applies so you have a downward force, the coriolis effect is a sideway force, those two combined should make you scratch your way further down into the core of the earth.

Yes there will be no terminal velocity, which is why he said you'd reach 10km/s on your first half of the journey through the earth (contrast with terminal velocity of something like 40-80m/s that skydivers experience depending on how aerodynamic they make themselves). 

It's also why you'd >just< make it to the other side of the Earth, because all the momentum built from the first half of the fall will be cancelled out by the negative acceleration experienced on the second half.

If the person reaches terminal velocity before he or she reaches the center, that means there's less acceleration time than there would be if the person continued to accelerate all the way to the center. Therefore, he or she would have less time for the negative acceleration to slow him or her down to a stopping point. The person would not make it all the way to the other side of the planet.

Terminal velocity only applies when you have air resistance, in this video they neglected air resistance. If you do have air resistance then you can only go as fast as terminal velocity where the force of air resistance exactly cancels the pull of gravity. As you get closer to the center the pull of gravity tends to zero and so terminal velocity tends to zero too. Methinks:

The Earth is spinning east, therefore and object at the surface is spinning east. An object on the surface of the Earth travels at the same speed and in the same direction as the surface of the Earth, which is where the speed is greatest. Going down, Earth's mass is still all spinning east, but at decreasing rates. The object would fall down, but still have the same eastward speed it had at the surface so it would continue to go east, faster than its surroundings, into the east wall.
as it goes down the radius is decreasing while the angular velocity would stay the same, so eventually it would be going faster than the walls. You forgot conservation of angular momentum ;)

Someone probably already answered this, but here I go. There are two main "theories" on this. One "model" was created by Einstein and is part of his general theory of relativity, and basically describes gravity as bends, or warps in space-time. So you are not being pulled towards something, but following a straight path. A seconds "theory" was created by the standard model (the thing that predicted the higgs boson). It says that another boson particle (the graviton) pulls all things together.
They actually don't know the answer to that question yet; there are many different theories being tested on it, lots of which are very confusing and make my brain hurt.

Imagine the space-time continuum as a trampoline, and imagine earth as a bowling ball. When something with large enough mass is placed in space-time, it causes it to bend and warp around it. Space, or rather space time, is NOT nothing.  I want you to think of space-time as a tempurpedic foam, ok?  When you drop something on tempurpedic foam, it sinks, creating an indent.  So lets call the
Earth a bowling ball.  When you drop the bowling ball on the foam, you get an indent.

When you put something near the dent, like a penny, the penny slides towards Earth.  That is gravity.  Gravity is the dent in space-time.
